page.title: 14NORTH DOWNS WAY PUTTENHAM
page.content: There is an ancient route of lanes and footpaths between Winchester and Canterbury which has long been known as the{Pilgrims Way.}Hilaire Belloc walked it and wrote about it in "The Old Road." Mediaeval fairs were held in Puttenham to attract the custom of the Pilgrims. This route has recently been sign- posted as one of the long distance foot-paths and is now known as the {North Downs Way.}It enters Puttenham at Totford Hatch, crosses the Common and passes Lascombe House, designed by Lutyens, before it forms part of the village street. It crosses the golf course on Puttenhem Heath and passes under the A3, where it is marked by two giant crosses. The North Downs Way enters Compton near the Watts Gallery and continues up the hill to Guildford.
